comments.body: â€œnever appears to need bracketingâ€ seems a bit too unsure to make me comfortable :slightly_smiling_face:. I donâ€™t really know how GHC resolves precedences but it seems like you could end up with `(setField @"foo" x y) + z` instead of `setField @"foo" x (y + z)`. Have you tested this and similar cases, e.g., it would also be interesting to have another function application there so `y z`.
We probably at least want to have some test cases that hit this.

`rupd_expr` is the record part of the update in `RecordUpd {rupd_expr; rupd_fields}`. I think there are 3 possibilities : `rupd_expr` is a var, `rupd_expr` is an application, `rupd_expr` is a record constructor/update. (1) doesn't need bracketing, (2) needs to be in brackets already or it won't parse and (3) never needs bracketing.
I'll fix the comment. I agree it doesn't inspire confidence :) I wrote it based on practice before I'd convinced myself by theory.

(1) `-- 'rupd_expr' never needs bracketing.`
(2) `-- Don't bracket here. The argument came in as a section so it's already enclosed in brackets.`

Iâ€™m still not convinced, sorry :slightly_smiling_face:  In particular, I am not convinced that 2 holds. If I have `x { a = y, b = z }` I believe you will first rewrite this to `setField @"a" x { b = z }` and then when you rewrite this it breaks.
Which 2 is it that you are not convinced holds?

> â€œnever appears to need bracketingâ€ seems a bit too unsure to make me comfortable ðŸ™‚. I donâ€™t really know how GHC resolves precedences but it seems like you could end up with `(setField @"foo" x y) + z` instead of `setField @"foo" x (y + z)`. Have you tested this and similar cases, e.g., it would also be interesting to have another function application there so `y z`.

Here's some tests that I think covers those?
```
data C = C {a : Int, b: Int}
g x y z = x {a = y, b = z}
h x y z = x {a = y + z}

mkC a b = C with a, b

main = scenario do
  let x = C {a = 1, b = 2}
  let x' = g x 3 4
  assert $ x'.a == 3 && x'.b == 4

  let x'' = h x 1 2
  assert $ x''.a == 3

  let x''' = h (mkC 5 6) 1 1
  assert $ x'''.a == 2
```

One more from above you asked for and I missed `i x y =  x {a = succ y}` :
```
  let x'''' = i C {a = 1, b = 2} 2
  assert $ x''''.a == 3
```

If it works then all is good but Iâ€™m still not sure I understand how it works. Is it as simple as GHC doesnâ€™t care if `rupd_expr` has parentheses or not? It seems like you will definitely not always have parentheses around the expression if there are multiple field updates.

comments.body: This is not about `:` is it? At least according to the comment above this is about sections on record accessors so `(.foo.bar)`. It is also not clear to me how this ends up looking in the AST. Do we end up with `mkParen (SectionR â€¦)` or does the whole thing parse as `SectionR â€¦`? In the latter case, removing the parenthesis is not going to work.

This is about sections. It is lexically impossible to write a "raw" section in Haskell - they must be parenthesized. That means that the expression being transformed is in the context of an enclosing brackets. Bracketing here the causes double ups `((expr))`.
